data.title: improve incremental search
data.body:
The current search function is very limited. In particular, it:
- Does not handle multiple cursors - it replaces all the cursors with the current search result.
- Has a separate focus from the text editor, which can be distracting to the user because they have to think about switching between editing and searching. In contrast, Visual Studio has a simple "inline" [incremental search mode](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/f27e8wzh%28v=vs.90%29.aspx) (ctrl+i) that maintains the focus in the editor, but captures the user's typing to create a search term. I propose that the user should be able to use either input mode; each has its advantages depending on the situation.
- Regular expression capturing groups are ignored (why not turn each captured group into its own selection?).

_Use case example:_ when editing JSON, I find the multiple cursors very useful, but there are times when ctrl+left/right do not move all of the cursors to the correct position because of differences in word boundaries. I would like a way to advance each cursor to the next regexp match.

Two approaches to resolve this issue:
1. Search is an integral function of a text editor, so build these features in.
2. Maybe there are many ways of implementing search, so let the user pick a search extension that works for them. I have attempted to [implement this functionality as an extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=siegebell.incremental-search), but here are some of the issues blocking me from making it a "nice" experience:
   - Add API support to hook into the existing search UI. I'm currently using `showInputBox` -- it works pretty well, but lacks a way to cancel the box (#9377), currently has funny behavior when validation fails (#9376), and does not allow adding buttons to toggle regexp or case sensitivity.
   - Either provide an "inline text input mode" API to temporarily capture text input normally directed toward an editor without a dialog popup or change of focus, or allow an extension to implement this itself. The latter would require an API to unregister handling of the 'type' command so as not to destroy the regular editing experience (#9384).

data.title: Feature Request: Horizontal split in addition to the vertical split
data.body:
I am submitting a feature request here, because the page to do feature requests does not work (https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/293070-visual-studio-code).

My feature request is for a horizontal split in addition to a vertical split. Currently, you can only view tabs next to each other, but I'd like to be able to view them top and bottom. This would be especially helpful when you have files that have really long lines of code.

data.title: Selecting a problem in the Problems panel should activate already-opened editor.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the Problems panel for a file with an open editor (ie `utilities.py`)
2. Switch focus to another editor stack (split view).
3. Click on one of the problems listed in the Problems pane.
4. A new editor opens with `utilities.py`, rather than switching to the currently open (but not active) editor.

data.title: Sort order for files in Explorer sidebar not natural/human
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

Steps to Reproduce:
    Open folder containing numerically labelled files:
        - 1.py, 2.py. 3.py ... 10.py, 11.py
Expectation:
    Files listed in explorer sidebar sorted in numerical order, as above (and as in Windows Explorer).
Actual outcome:
    Files sorted lexicographically:
        1.py, 10.py, 11.py, 2.py, 3.py ...
See https://blog.codinghorror.com/sorting-for-humans-natural-sort-order/

data.title: Search results need more space than the side bar allows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X

I believe that often, search results need more horizontal space to be truly useful than the sidebar allows, unless you expand the sidebar very wide (which then means less room for open files, and requires you to manually resize it bigger and smaller when going between search and editing, if you like to have the file tree open when editing).

My suggestion would be that search should have the option to display the results in a new tab, in a similar way to Atom or Sublime, or alternatively, the search pane could be relocatable to the bottom of the screen, so it would gain horizontal space in exchange for vertical.

data.title: showTabs: false creates "invisible" tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Disable tabs (`workbench.editor.showTabs: false`).
2. Create a vertical split.
3. Open a few files in the editor (in one of the panes)
4. Hit `cmd+w`

It closes an "invisible tab", it doesn't close the whole pane as it used to.

This sucks mostly because I use two vertical panes. And every now and then, I want to close one of the panes to only have a big single editor window. Now in order to close one of the panes, I have to close a number of tabs which I can't even see.

data.title: Tab order in Search window is not optimal for some use cases
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X

I find the tab order in the search window is not optimal for the way I tend to use it – I primarily use search to find strings in certain types of files, so I might e.g. search for `user` in `*.ts`, then next I might want to search for `user-container` in `*.less`. 

In Atom and Sublime, the "files to include" field is one tab keypress away from the "search string" field, which makes doing this kind of search very easy. 

In VS Code, the tab order goes from the search string field to the three options (case sensitive, whole word and regex), then to the `...` expand link, and only then to the "files to include" box, so it takes five tab key presses to switch from "search string" to "files to include" (or a mouse move and click, but often that is less convenient). 

To my mind it would make sense for `tab` to first (or only?) tab through just the input fields, and to make use of keyboard shortcuts to enable/disable the options, although perhaps this is just me coming from Sublime/Atom. Alternatively, a separate keyboard shortcut could move through the input fields – in fact, it seems `Alt+Down arrow` will move from "search string" to "files to include", but not back again.

I'd be happy to try and implement this if you could advise on what a preferred solution (if any) might be!

data.title: Poor performance on large resolution

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Version: VSCode Insiders.
Latest OS X

I have a secondary monitor plugged into my MacBook pro which has 3840 x 2160 pixels. I have my resolution set to 2560 x 1440.

When I resize vscode to use the full size of the screen, there is about ~300ms - ~500ms of lag when editing a medium size file (~300 LOC in a TypeScript file). I haven't tried to compare this performance with smaller and larger files, however I have noticed that editing an empty file is much faster.

I'm not sure how I can provide more information, but do let me know if you need anything else.

data.title: recent folder not opening mac
Cannot download OmniSharp
data.body:
Hello everyone,

I'm not sure if this is a VS Code or OmniSharp issue, so feel free to move it to the right repository if necessary.

When I open a .Net project, I get the following in Output window:

```
[INFO] Starting OmniSharp at 'c:\Users\xyz\Documents\My Web Sites\SomeProject'...
[INFO] Installing to C:\Users\xyz\.vscode\extensions\ms-vscode.csharp-1.2.2\.omnisharp
[INFO] Attempting to download omnisharp-1.9-beta11-win-x64-net451.zip...
```

And it gets stuck there. Nothing is downloaded and my project doesn't have any kind of Intellisense (obviously).

Maybe this is relevant, and maybe not, but at work, we are behind a firewall and a proxy server (from Fortinet) that does strange stuff. One of which is using its own certificate for all HTTPS requests, which I faced an issue with when using an application that require a valid  certificate signed by trusted CA, or an application that uses certificate pinning technique.
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go behind our proxy.
2. Open a .Net project :)

data.title: Where to ask architecture based questions?
data.body:
I am sorry for possibly posting this at the wrong place. I would like to extend vscode, however I have a few questions related to its architecture. Do you guys have a slack or similar soft Q-A account? Stackoverflow is very strict on asking soft questions without well defined answers which is why I have come here.

I specifically want to know the way intellisense provides suggestions, and which files I should be interested in.

data.title: TypeScript / Solution prompts to Common Problems [Feature Request]
data.body:
In Visual C#, I'm very used to visual studio prompting me solutions to common problems like adding variable declarations and creating a file with a template ready to be used.

I know TypeScript is lot different than C#, these prompts speed the development process a huge bunch.

IMHO, I would love to see/use :

**PROBLEM FIXES**
1. **Undeclared variables**: if a variable is not defined prompt me to add it either as a local variable a global variable or a global variable declaration
2. **Forgotten `this`**: I wish TypeScript would stop asking me to type `this` (or make it optional :ghost:), but no I forget it all the time, would love a fast way to refactor that (one click and boom :smile:); if there is a member with that name prompt me to refactor and add it
3. **Undeclared member values**: Also, after working with pure JS, you forget that you have to declare them in TypeScript
4. **Undeclared instantiated/extended classes**: if say in `new Texture("player.png")`, `Texture` is not yet declared prompt to add an implementation or a declaration for it
5. **Undeclared implemented/extended interfaces**: if say in `interface B extends A {}` or `class C implements A`, `A` is not yet declared prompt to add an a declaration for it
6. **Undeclared callable**: you know the gist, if its a function/method call ask me to declare it
7. **Declare in a new file**: would love for **4** and **6** to add the option to declare them in a separate file, just the class declaration as default and make the template configurable globally or per project

**PS**: please make it work also with Symbols

**CODE GEN**
1. **Genarate a constructor**<sup>*</sup>
2. **Generate getters and setters**<sup>*</sup>: C# property equiv.
3. **Generate getters**<sup>*</sup>
4. **Generate setters**<sup>*</sup>
5. **Extract method**: when a statement or more are selected, add extraction utility
6. **Generate method**
7. **Generate toString**
8. **Generate [Symbol.iterator]**

<sup>*</sup>: from member declarations

**PS**: in **2** here is what I meant;

``` TypeScript
private _name: string;
public get name() { return this._name; }
public set name(value: string) { this._name = value; }
```

data.title: TypeScrypt highlighting gets confused on lambda functions
Wrong autocomplete order/selection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create TypeScript file
2. Enter the following code

```
const test1 = 5
const test = {
    a: 1
}
```
1. Type `test.`

Problem:
VSCode will autocomplete with `test1.`

Here is the screenshot of what VScode highlights by default when `test` is typed in - and pressing `.` will select it (notice that order is incorrect - test1 should be below test)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/16903370/46230964-4c4a-11e6-8b5d-8324c715c617.png)

For comparison this is VSCode 1.3.1:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/16903374/55517c7c-4c4a-11e6-9187-ac95c9aa20ba.png)

Unfortunately it might be related to the project, because if I try to recreate it with empty project then it was fine.

data.title: VSCode touches file twice when saving file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise 64-Bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. NodeJS watcher on file (e.g. watchify with browserify)
2. Update function gets called twice.

When editing the file with notepad, the watcher only fires one update.

Thanks for the great tool!! :+1:

data.title: Successive attempts to run Debug:Evaluate on selected text fail.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start a debug session
2. Select code to evaluate in an editor
3. Select 'Debug Evaluate' from the command menu
   - Evaluation succeeds.
4. Select 'Debug Evaluate' from the command menu a second time (with code still selected)
   - Evaluation fails with the Info message "Command 'Debug:Evaluate' is not enabled in the current context."

Any subsequent attempts to call 'Debug Evaluate' fail with the same message.

data.title: Ctrl + Tab not showing recently opened files after update to 1.3.1
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a few files
2. Press Ctrl + Tab and observe that only one file appears in the list. This was working fine before the update and a very crucial feature during development.
